question_text: Your password is 'Pizza123'. How long would it take a hacker to crack it?
explanation_feedback: Simple words + numbers are cracked instantly by AI tools. Use a phrase like 'Blue-Pizza-Sky-99' instead!

question_text: Is it safe to use the same password for your Email and your Bank?
explanation_feedback: Never reuse passwords! If one site gets hacked, thieves will try that password everywhere else.

question_text: Which of these is the strongest password?
explanation_feedback: Length and complexity matter. 'Tr0ub4dor&3' mixes letters, numbers, and symbols and isn't a common phrase.

question_text: What is a Password Manager?
options: An app that saves your passwords securely
explanation_feedback: A Password Manager is an app that generates and stores complex passwords for you, so you only need to remember one master password.

question_text: True or False: You should share your password with your best friend in case of emergency.
explanation_feedback: False. Never share passwords. If they get hacked or you have a falling out, your account is at risk.

question_text: What does '2FA' stand for?
explanation_feedback: Two-Factor Authentication adds a second lock (like a code on your phone) to your account.

question_text: You log into Facebook on a library computer. What must you do before leaving?
explanation_feedback: Always click 'Log Out'. Closing the window isn't enough; the next person could open it and be in your account.

question_text: A site asks for a 'Security Question'. Which is the safest answer for 'Mother's Maiden Name'?
explanation_feedback: Treat security questions like passwords. Real answers (like maiden names) can often be found on public records or social media.

question_text: You get an alert: 'New login from Russia'. You live in Ohio. What do you do?
explanation_feedback: This means someone else might be in your account. Change your password right away to kick them out.

question_text: Which is safer for receiving 2FA codes?
explanation_feedback: Authenticator Apps are safer. SMS messages can sometimes be intercepted by hackers swapping your SIM card.

question_text: You get an email from 'Amaz0n-Support' saying your order is delayed. What's the red flag?
explanation_feedback: Look closely at the spelling. Scammers replace 'o' with '0' or make other small typos to trick you.

question_text: An email says 'URGENT: Account Suspended! Click here now!'. What emotion are they using?
explanation_feedback: Scammers use fear to make you act without thinking. Stop, breathe, and verify before clicking.

question_text: You hover your mouse over a link that says 'PayPal'. The popup box shows 'http://pay-pal-secure-login.xyz'. Is it safe?
explanation_feedback: No! The actual URL (where the link goes) does not match the official 'paypal.com'. This is a trap.

question_text: An email starts with 'Dear Customer'. Why is this suspicious?
options: Real companies usually use your name
explanation_feedback: Generic greetings like 'Dear Customer' often mean the email was sent to millions of people at once by a scammer.

question_text: You receive an unexpected invoice attachment named 'Invoice_302.pdf.exe'. Should you open it?
options: Yes, to see what it is
explanation_feedback: Never open it! The '.exe' at the end means it's a program (likely a virus), not a real PDF document.

question_text: You get a text: 'USPS: We cannot deliver your package. Click here to update address.' You aren't expecting a package.
explanation_feedback: It's a scam. If you aren't expecting a package, don't click. Even if you are, go to the official USPS site directly.

question_text: A text says 'You won a $1000 Walmart Gift Card! Claim at bit.ly/winner'. What is 'bit.ly'?
options: A link shortener hiding the real destination
explanation_feedback: Link shorteners hide the true website address. Scammers use them to mask dangerous links.

question_text: You get a text from a random number: 'Hey John, are we still on for lunch?'. Your name is not John.
explanation_feedback: Ignore it. Replying confirms your number is active, leading to more spam. This is often the start of a 'Pig Butchering' scam.

question_text: Your bank texts you a code you didn't ask for, then calls asking for that code. Do you give it?
explanation_feedback: NEVER give a code to someone who calls you. Banks will never ask for it. The caller is a scammer trying to log into your account.

question_text: Why are SMS scams dangerous?
options: People trust texts more than emails
explanation_feedback: We are trained to trust texts and react quickly. Scammers exploit this 'personal' channel to lower your guard.

question_text: What does 'AI' stand for?
explanation_feedback: 'Artificial Intelligence' refers to computer systems designed to perform tasks that usually require human intelligence.

question_text: How does AI 'learn'?
options: It reads books like a human
It looks for patterns in huge amounts of data
explanation_feedback: AI analyzes vast datasets (like millions of photos) to find patterns (like 'what a cat looks like'). It doesn't 'read' or 'understand' like we do.

question_text: Which of these uses AI?
explanation_feedback: Netflix uses AI to analyze what you watch and predict what you might like next.

question_text: True or False: AI is always right.
explanation_feedback: False! AI can make mistakes, hallucinate facts, or be biased based on the data it was trained on.

question_text: What is a 'Chatbot'?
options: A computer program you can talk to via text
explanation_feedback: Chatbots (like ChatGPT or customer service bots) use AI to understand and generate human-like text responses.

question_text: Can AI create images that look like real photos?
explanation_feedback: Yes. AI tools can generate hyper-realistic images. This is why we must be careful about what we see online.

question_text: What is 'Voice Cloning'?
options: AI mimicking a person's voice from a short audio clip
explanation_feedback: AI can analyze a few seconds of someone's voice and then say ANYTHING in that voice. Scammers use this to impersonate loved ones.

question_text: What is a 'Deepfake'?
options: A fake video where a person's face is swapped with someone else's
explanation_feedback: Deepfakes are AI-manipulated videos. They can make it look like a celebrity or politician said something they never actually said.

question_text: Can AI write a school essay?
options: Yes, but it might be factually wrong
explanation_feedback: AI can write essays, but it often makes up facts (hallucinations). It's a tool for assistance, not a replacement for your own work.

question_text: Why should you be careful with AI?
options: It can be used to create convincing scams and fake news
explanation_feedback: The main risk for us is how bad actors use AI to trick us with fake emails, voices, and videos.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: You get a call from 'Grandma' saying she's in jail and needs $500 in Gift Cards. The voice sounds exactly like her.
options: Hang up and call her real number
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! Even if the voice is perfect, it could be AI. The request for 'Gift Cards' is the smoking gun. Always verify offline.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: You receive an email with a link to 'Reset Password'. The sender is 'support@g0ogle.com'.
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! 'g0ogle.com' is a fake domain. You spotted the zero! Never click links from misspelled domains.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: Which password is safest?
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! A long passphrase like 'Correct-Horse-Battery-Staple' is much harder for AI to crack than short complex ones.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: You see a video of the President declaring war, but it's not on any major news channel.
options: Assume it's a Deepfake and check other sources
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! If a major event isn't on major news, it's likely a Deepfake designed to cause panic. Verify before you share.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: A website asks for your 2FA code to 'verify your identity' after you already logged in.
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! This is a 'Man-in-the-Middle' attack. If you are already logged in, you shouldn't need to re-enter codes on a random page.
